com.pb.sawdust.util.concurrent

Class DnCRecursivePrimitiveAction

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.util.concurrent.DnCRecursivePrimitiveAction

  • public class DnCRecursivePrimitiveAction
extends java.lang.Object
    The DnCRecursivePrimitiveAction provides simple abstract RecursiveAction implementations for dealing with primitives. As the intention behind these classes is to avoid autoboxing, even procedures which naturally would be executed through DnCRecursiveTasks should use one of these classes, as DnCRecursiveTask will perform autoboxing in its combination of sub-task results.

    To give an example of how a primitive task may be reformulated as an action, the following code example shows a primitive action which takes a double array and computes the sum of the squares of its values (this is the primitive equivalent of the example in DnCRecursiveTask). To get the final result, getResult() would be called. 

    
     public class ArraySquareSum extends DnCRecursiveDoubleAction {
         private final double[] array;

         public ArraySquareSum(double[] array) {
             super(0,array.length);
             this.array = array;
         }

         private ArraySquareSum(double[] array, long start, long length, DnCRecursiveTask<Double> next) {
             super(start,length,next);
             this.array = array;
         }

         protected void computeAction(long start, long length) {
             long end = start + length;
             double sum = 0.0;
             for (long i = start; i < end; i++)
                 sum += array[i]*array[i];
             setResult(sum);
         }

         protected DnCRecursiveDoubleAction getNextTask(long start, long length, DnCRecursiveDoubleAction next) {
             return new ArraySquareSum(array,start,length,next);
         }

         protected boolean continueDividing(long newLength) {
             return getSurplusQueuedTaskCount() < 3;
         }
     }
    The idiom for primitive actions is slightly different than that shown in the DnCRecursiveAction documentation, because of the additional framework set up to handle primitive tasks. Specifically the combineResults method must be overridden to (effectively) do nothing. Here is the example from the DnCRecursiveAction class reformulated to deal with primitives: 
    
     public class ArraySquarer extends DnCRecursiveDoubleAction {
         private final double[] array;

         public ArraySquarer(double[] array) {
             super(0,array.length);
             this.array = array;
         }

         private ArraySquarer(double[] array, long start, long length, DnCRecursiveAction next) {
             super(start,length,next);
             this.array = array;
         }

         protected void computeAction(long start, long length) {
             long end = start + length;
             for (long i = start; i < end; i++)
                 array[i] = array[i]*array[i];
         }

         protected DnCRecursiveAction getNextAction(long start, long length, DnCRecursiveAction next) {
             return new ArraySquarer(array,start,length,next);
         }

         protected boolean continueDividing(long newLength) {
             return getSurplusQueuedTaskCount() < 3;
         }

         protected double combineResults(double thisResult, double subActionResult) {
             return thisResult; //stub that will be ignored in practice
         }
     }
